extractedContent:
Application Number: 242705
Filename: FAMILY FIRST HEALTH CORPORATION_Application-242705.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T04:13:41.574Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the Project Narrative, the applicant states: 'The most recent Community Health Needs Assessment was released in the summer of 2025. The assessment is compiled by WellSpan Health, and accounts for all four (4) counties in our service area (Adams, Lancaster, Lebanon, and York). The previous assessment was released in 2022. The assessment leverages data from multiple data sources, including: WellSpan Health patient data, WellSpan Health's provider survey; local, state and national data sources; representative and special populations community survey; and special populations data collection. Family First Health is one of many partners in the process led by our largest regional health system, WellSpan. The data collection and analysis process takes place every three years, with actions to address identified areas of improvement taking place on an ongoing basis.' The narrative further details how the needs assessment is used to inform service delivery, resource allocation, and planning, and references annual review of UDS data, zip code analysis, and patient/community input. The application also describes use of the 2025 WellSpan CHNA and 2025 UPMC CHNA, both updated every three years, and provides specific data from these assessments throughout the needs assessment section.
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant demonstrates that a comprehensive needs assessment is completed or updated at least every three years (2022 and 2025), uses the most recent available data, covers the full service area and special populations, and is used to inform and improve service delivery. The process is ongoing, collaborative, and data-driven, with evidence of regular review and integration into planning and operations. This meets the HRSA requirement for Element b.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13 - Health Center Program Requirements Compliance states: 'Per our Sliding Fee Discount Program policy (revised and approved by our Board of Directors on ), "any patient who falls at or below 200% of Federal Poverty Guidelines, as determined by income and family size will be eligible for the Sliding Fee Discount program."' The policy is described as board-approved and is referenced as applying to all patients. The Project Narrative and Attachment 13 further detail uniform application, methods for assessing eligibility, and adjustment of charges based on ability to pay. Form 1C confirms the existence of board-approved policies and procedures for the Sliding Fee Discount Program.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence of a board-approved sliding fee discount policy that applies uniformly to all patients, as required. The policy addresses eligibility, income/family size, and adjustment of charges. The policy is referenced as being reviewed and approved by the board, and the process is described in detail in both the narrative and compliance attachment.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A shows that all required primary care, dental, behavioral health, optometry, and podiatry services are provided directly (Column I). The sliding fee schedules for medical, dental, and pharmacy are included in Attachment 10 and summarized in the narrative and compliance attachment. The schedules show discount levels based on income and family size, with nominal charges for those at or below 100% FPG, and increasing discounts up to 200% FPG. The Project Narrative and Attachment 13 confirm that these schedules are applied to all directly provided services, and the policy is reviewed and approved annually by the board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center provides all required services directly (per Form 5A, Column I), and the sliding fee discount schedules are structured according to policy and HRSA requirements. The schedules provide discounts for all required services, including nominal charges for the lowest income group, and are consistent with the policy described in the application.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: The sliding fee schedules in Attachment 10 (FFH Sliding Fee Discount Charts 2025.pdf) and the compliance narrative explicitly state they are based on the 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines. The Project Narrative and Attachment 13 state: 'Our current scales contain the 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines for income and household size.' The process for annual review and update of the schedules based on the most recent FPG is described, and the schedules themselves show the correct 2025 FPG values.
compliantItems.reasoning: The evidence demonstrates that the most recent Federal Poverty Guidelines (2025) have been incorporated into the sliding fee schedules, as required by HRSA. The schedules are updated annually, and the current version uses the correct FPG values.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff (FFH Position Descriptons Key Management.pdf) and Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff (Attachment 5 - FFH bios for key management staff.pdf) are included in the application. The job descriptions for President/CEO, VP of Finance & Information Systems, VP of Medical Services, and VP of Operations and Quality are provided in detail, including essential duties, required qualifications (education and experience), and required skills/abilities. Biographical sketches further document the experience and qualifications of the individuals in these roles.
compliantItems.reasoning: HRSA requires that key management staff positions have documented duties/functions and qualifications. The application provides both detailed job descriptions and biographical sketches for all key management staff, demonstrating compliance with this requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists the Project Director/Chief Executive Officer (CEO) as a direct hire (1.00 FTE, no contract/NO). The job description for President/CEO (Attachment 4) states the supervisor is the Board of Directors. The bylaws (Attachment 2) Article VI, Section A.8 state: 'The Board of Directors will be responsible for the hiring, supervision, and discharge of the Chief Executive Officer.' The job description also states the CEO 'leads, motivates and facilitates the development of a senior leadership team' and 'is responsible for the recruitment, employment, and release of all personnel.' The organizational chart (Attachment 3) shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the Board, and overseeing all other key management staff.
compliantItems.reasoning: The CEO is directly employed by Family First Health (not a contractor), reports to the governing board as required by the bylaws and job description, and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff and day-to-day operations. All required aspects of Element d are met.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists contracts and referral agreements (e.g., AccessNurse, WellSpan Health, Life Changing Pathways, etc.), and the application narrative describes contract management, follow-up processes, and compliance with HRSA requirements. The application also references procurement and conflict of interest policies (Form 1C), and the Board-approved bylaws (Attachment 2) include conflict of interest and procurement standards.
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center has provided a summary of all contracts and agreements, including details on services, delivery methods, timeframes, and follow-up processes. The application narrative and Form 1C confirm that required policies and procedures (procurement, conflict of interest, financial management) are in place and current. There is no evidence of missing or non-compliant contract provisions.

notApplicableItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2a: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' Answer: No. Narrative and Attachment 7 confirm no such contracts.
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center states it does not contract with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work (i.e., does not contract for a majority of health care providers or core clinical services). Therefore, HRSA prior approval is not required and this element is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' Answer: No. Narrative and Attachment 13 confirm: 'Family First Health does not have any sub-recipients or subawards with 330 funding.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center confirms it does not have any subawards or subrecipients with 330 funding. Therefore, HRSA prior approval to subaward is not required and this element is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' Answer: No. Narrative and Attachment 13 confirm: 'Family First Health does not have any sub-recipients or subawards with 330 funding.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center confirms it does not have any subawards or subrecipients with 330 funding. Therefore, subaward agreement provisions are not applicable.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application provides extensive narrative and documentation of collaborative relationships with local hospitals (e.g., WellSpan York Hospital), specialty providers (e.g., Leg Up Farm for pediatric therapies), and social service organizations (e.g., Bell Socialization Services, Community Progress Council, Catholic Harvest Food Pantry, York County Food Bank, York Fresh Food Farms, Sparrow Place, Life Changing Pathways, LifePath Christian Ministries). Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation includes letters of support from WellSpan York Hospital, Leg Up Farm, the School District of the City of York, and Bell Socialization Services, which all describe the nature and benefits of these collaborations. The Project Narrative and Attachments 7 and 9 detail how these relationships provide access to services not available through the health center, such as pediatric therapies, domestic violence support, housing, food assistance, and recovery support.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application meets the requirement by providing clear, specific, and current documentation of collaborative relationships with a range of providers and programs in the service area. There is evidence of both formal agreements (Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements) and active partnerships (Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation and letters of support). The narrative describes how these collaborations increase access to specialty and enabling services not available directly through the health center, and how they support special populations. The evidence is robust and directly responsive to the requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The Project Narrative (see 'How the overlap of political subdivisions, school districts, and areas served by Federal and State health and social programs affect access to primary health care services in the service area') describes coordination with federal and state programs such as Medicaid, CHIP, and the 340B program. The application specifically lists four neighboring FQHCs with service areas that border Family First Health's (FFH's) service area: Keystone Health, Sadler Health, Hamilton Health, and Union Community Care. The narrative states: 'This boundary coordination with other CHCs makes sure that community members have access to our or their services, depending on where they live and which services are most convenient.' The application also describes active participation in the Pennsylvania Association of Community Health Centers (PACHC), the state PCA, and the Health Center Controlled Network (HCCN) 'Keys to Quality,' which facilitates collaboration, training, and data sharing among health centers. There is documentation of relationships with local health departments, school districts, and social service agencies. Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements and Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation further support these claims.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence of efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, state, and local health services delivery projects and programs, including other health centers. The explicit mention of neighboring FQHCs, participation in the PCA and HCCN, and documented relationships with public health and social service agencies demonstrate compliance. The evidence is sufficient and directly addresses the requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence: Appendix A: Health Center Program Requirements Compliance states: 'FFH fully participates in all Medicaid plans serving our geography, in addition fully participates in plans aligned with those utilizing the health center services. Plan participation is evaluated annually and on an as needed basis. This responsibility is held by the fiscal department.' Form 3 - Income Analysis shows revenue from Medicaid, Medicare, Private, and Self Pay. Project Narrative also states: 'we accept a wide range of insurance plans, as well as serving uninsured and underinsured patients from across these counties.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear and direct evidence of participation in Medicaid, Medicare, and private insurance programs, with explicit statements of participation and supporting financial data. There is no indication that CHIP is excluded, and the language 'all Medicaid plans' and 'plans aligned with those utilizing the health center services' reasonably includes CHIP as required. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence: Appendix A: Health Center Program Requirements Compliance provides the following: 'Per our "Waiving Fees" policy approved by the Board of Directors on : "It is the policy of Family First Health to approve the waiving of fees for patients in certain hardship situations..." The Procedure for this policy is as follows: "Family First Health's President/Chief Executive Officer and Vice President of Finance may approve waiving the patient portion of all fees, including any nominal fees, Sliding Scale Discount fees, or copays for patients in certain situations including, but not limited to the following: Natural or manmade disasters (flood, fire, etc.), Catastrophic medical event or illness, Victim of Violent Crime/Domestic Abuse. Patients are expected to provide appropriate information/documentation regarding these hardship situations. Documentation of waiver of fees will be made in the patient record. Waiver of fees will be valid for 90 days and may be renewed another 90 days only following reassessment and approval as described above. After 180 days the patient will apply for the Sliding Fee Discount Program. Patients experiencing hardship situations will be offered assistance from social services and behavioral health.' Form 1C confirms such policies are on file.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a board-approved policy and detailed procedures specifying the circumstances under which fees may be waived or reduced (e.g., disasters, catastrophic illness, crime victimization), documentation requirements, approval authority, and timeframes. This meets HRSA's requirement for both policy and operational procedure, including specificity regarding circumstances and process. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes the SF-424A: Budget Information - Non-Construction Programs, Budget Narrative, and Budget Justification, which detail a total budget of $40,817,220.00. This budget is broken down by object class (personnel, fringe, supplies, contractual, etc.), revenue sources (federal, state, local, program income, other federal, other support), and is consistent across all budget documents. The narrative explicitly states: 'The attached budget forms and budget narrative are consistent and support our work plan to support our organization's efforts to ensure quality care for our patients. This includes all of our work in the areas of medical, dental, behavioral health, vision, podiatry, enabling services, and pharmacy.' The budget supports the projected patient growth and expanded services described in the Project Narrative and aligns with the scope of project as outlined in Forms 5A, 5B, and 5C.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a complete, detailed, and consistent annual budget that covers all projected costs and revenues necessary to support the full HRSA-approved scope of project. The budget narrative and forms directly tie to the scope of services and patient projections, demonstrating compliance with HRSA requirements for budgeting for the scope of project.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A, Budget Narrative, and Form 3: Income Analysis all detail revenue sources beyond the HRSA award. These include: Program Income ($25,192,871), State Funds ($2,316,323), Local Funds ($466,938), Other Federal Funding ($2,210,179), Other Support ($7,758,032), and detailed breakdowns of Medicaid, Medicare, Private, Self-Pay, and 340B revenue. Table 16 and Table 59 (Form 3) show all categories of revenue, and the narrative confirms: 'Our budget for the first year of this grant totals $40,817,220.00. We are requesting $2,872,877.00 via this grant (per the published amount on the SAAT) and will match with $37,944,343.00. These budget numbers reflect the funding needed to support the number of patients that we project serving.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application clearly includes all projected revenue sources in the annual budget, not just the HRSA award. The budget forms and narrative provide a comprehensive accounting of federal, state, local, program income, and other sources, fully meeting HRSA's requirement to include all revenue supporting the Health Center Program project.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article VI, Section A, states: 'The Board of Directors will be responsible for the hiring, supervision, and discharge of the Chief Executive Officer.' Article VI, Section A, also states: 'The Board of Directors will be responsible for approving Health Center Program services and the location and hours of operation of health center sites (Forms 5A, 5B, and 5C).' Article VI, Section A, further states: 'The Board of Directors will have full authority and responsibility for the annual Health Center Program budget, financial management policies, and applications.' Article IX, Section C, states: 'the Board of Directors has full authority and responsibility for establishing personnel policies, health care related policies, evaluating center activities and assuring that the Corporation is operating in compliance with federal, state and local laws and regulations.' The application narrative and Attachment 13 further confirm that no other individual, entity, or committee reserves approval authority or has veto power over the board regarding required authorities and functions.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly assign all required authorities to the Board of Directors, including CEO selection/dismissal, budget and application approval, services and site approval, policy establishment, and compliance oversight. The application narrative and compliance attachment confirm that no other entity or agreement restricts the board's authority, and the organizational chart shows direct reporting to the board. There is no evidence of conflicting authority. Therefore, the health center is compliant with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article V, Section B: 'Regular meetings of the Board of Directors of the Corporation shall be held at least monthly, normally on the 4th Tuesday of the month.' Article VI, Section A, Number 8: 'The Board of Directors will be responsible for the hiring, supervision, and discharge of the Chief Executive Officer.' Article VI, Section A, Number 10: 'The Board of Directors will have full authority and responsibility for the annual Health Center Program budget, financial management policies, and applications.' Article VI, Section A, Number 9: 'The Board of Directors will be responsible for approving Health Center Program services and the location and hours of operation of health center sites (Forms 5A, 5B, and 5C).' Article IX, Section C: 'the Board of Directors has full authority and responsibility for establishing personnel policies, health care related policies, evaluating center activities and assuring that the Corporation is operating in compliance with federal, state and local laws and regulations.' Attachment 13 (Program Requirements Compliance) cross-references these sections and confirms board authority for all required functions. The application narrative and organizational chart show no delegation of these authorities to other entities or committees.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws and compliance documentation explicitly address all required board authorities: monthly meetings, CEO selection/dismissal, budget and application approval, service and site approval, policy establishment, and compliance oversight. The application confirms that no other entity or agreement restricts these authorities. There is no evidence of non-compliance or missing authority. Therefore, the health center is compliant with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article III (Board of Directors Membership) and Article VI (Governing Bodies), as well as Article IV (Officers), specify that board members are nominated by the Governance Committee and approved by majority vote of the Board of Directors. Article VI, Section A.5 states: 'Any member may be removed from the Board of Directors and from membership on the Board of Directors by majority vote of the remaining members of the Board of Directors whenever in their judgement the best interests of the Corporation will be served by removing that member.' Article IV, Section D.1-3: 'Nominations for offices shall be made by a Governance Committee appointed by the Chair... An election of officers shall be held at the annual meeting of the Corporation in September of each year.' There is no indication that any outside entity, committee, or individual outside the board has authority to select the board chair or a majority of board members.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly outline that the board itself, through its Governance Committee and majority vote, is responsible for the selection, nomination, and removal of board members and officers. There is no language permitting any other entity, committee, or individual to select the board chair or the majority of board members. This meets HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article VI, Section A.1 states: 'The Board shall consist of at least nine (9), and no more than 15, members. At least 50%+1 Board members shall be consumers of Family First Health services as defined by the Bureau of Primary Healthcare. In addition, no more than 50% of the non-consumer Board members will derive greater than 10% of their annual income from the health care industry.' Article VI, Section A.2: 'The Board shall demographically reflect the clients served by the Corporation, as well as be representative of the geographic service area and collectively possess the expertise required to govern the organization.' Article III, Section A prohibits employees and their immediate family members from serving on the board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws specify all required elements: board size (9-15), patient majority, demographic and geographic representation, expertise, and restrictions on health industry income and employee/family membership. This matches HRSA requirements for board composition.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics lists 10 board members, with columns for area of expertise, health center patient status, and whether they live or work in the service area. At least 6 of 10 are marked as health center patients (Allison Hawthorne, Carlos Roberts, Phillip Given, Robert Merino, Michael Shanebrook, Kenneth Adams), meeting the 51% patient majority requirement. The board includes members with expertise in community affairs, behavioral health, human resources, healthcare, community organizing, finance, human services, and business. Only one member (Carlos Roberts) is listed as earning >10% of income from the health industry, and only among non-patient members. All members live or work in the service area. No employees or immediate family members are listed.
compliantItems.reasoning: The board meets the minimum size, patient majority, expertise, and representation requirements. There is no evidence of non-compliance with HRSA board composition standards.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements states: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' On Form 1A, only CHC-330(e) funding is requested; no funding is requested under 330(g), 330(h), or 330(i).
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The applicant is a 330(e) Community Health Center and is not requesting a waiver of patient majority board composition. Therefore, this requirement does not apply.
